title: Jizaikake
text: Activity within traditional Japanese farm families typically centered around a central open hearth (<I>irori<I>). This massive wooden hook (<I>jizaikake<I>) would have been suspended from the beams of a house. Cooking kettles or an iron teapot would have been suspended over the fire by a rope attached to the hook.  This style of <I>jizaikake<I> is popularly referred to as Daikoku, a popular kitchen god, because its cap-like top section suggests Daikoku's hat.
description: inverted V-shaped top section with two square pegs; very large, thick hook below top section; with wooden base; medium finish on hook and base
creditline: Gift of Harriet and Edson Spencer
